title: Corrections: June 27, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, June 27, 2023.
content: An article on Sunday about a man who was charged with murder in the fentanyl overdose of his friend misstated the circumstances of a case in Tennessee. A 17-year-old girl was charged after she shared fentanyl with two friends, not three. Both friends died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: Despite Global Pledges, Tree Loss Is Up Sharply in Tropical Forests
description: The pace of deforestation increased 10 percent in 2022, but there are signs the trajectory may change for the better in the near future.
content: More than a year after countries pledged to end deforestation by 2030, the world is continuing to lose its tropical forests at a fast pace, according to a report issued on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Prince Harry’s Lawyers Make Closing Remarks: What to Know About the Court Case
description: The prince has sued a British media company, Mirror Group Newspapers, claiming that reporters hacked his phone more than a decade ago.
content: Prince Harry’s lawyers began their closing statements on Tuesday in a lawsuit against the British media company Mirror Group Newspapers, which he has accused of hacking his cellphone more than a decade ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Out of Sight,’ 25 Years Later
description: This adaptation of an Elmore Leonard novel broke a losing streak for Steven Soderbergh and gave George Clooney a boost up the movie star ladder.
content: In a journal entry dated Jan. 30, 1997, (and published in his book “Getting Away With It”), the director Steven Soderbergh writes of a meeting with Casey Silver, the chairman of Universal’s film division, who “asked if he could secretly slip me a copy of ‘Out of Sight,’” a screen adaptation of an Elmore Leonard novel the studio was set to produce with George Clooney in the leading role. “I said sure, I’d read it right away, and I did,” Soderbergh wrote. “It’s a terrific script and all the people involved are good, so of course I called Casey the next day and turned it down.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Elizabeth Oliver, Carmen K. Sisson and David Montgomery
title: ‘It’s Dangerous’: Heat Wave Spreads From Texas to Bake the Southeast
description: Excessive heat could last in some parts of the region through the Fourth of July.
content: A scorching early-summer heat wave that has baked much of Texas and Oklahoma for the past week spread across the Gulf Coast on Tuesday, with dangerous heat forecasts reaching all the way to the Florida Keys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan
title: The Attention Was All on Mar-a-Lago. Some of the Action Was at Bedminster.
description: The inquiry into Donald Trump’s handling of classified material revolved largely around his Florida club and residence, but investigators were also quietly focused on his New Jersey property.
content: For all the attention focused during the investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s handling of classified documents on Mar-a-Lago, his private club and residence in Florida, another of Mr. Trump’s properties has played a crucial, if quieter, role in the case: his 520-acre golf club in Bedminster, N.J.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed O'Loughlin
title: Call of the Rewild: Restoring Ecological Health to the Emerald Isle
description: Centuries of overgrazing and deforestation have eliminated most native flora in Ireland, creating what ecologists see as a man-made desert in places. A growing “rewilding” push aims to change that.
content: The west coast of Ireland is famed for its wave-beaten shores and bare, stony mountains, where only a few stunted trees grow in hollows and valleys, bent by harsh storms blowing in from the North Atlantic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Putin, Prigozhin and the Danger of Disorder
description: The events playing out in Russia last weekend felt like the trailer for the next James Bond movie.
content: The events playing out in Russia feel like the trailer for the next James Bond movie: Vladimir Putin’s ex-chef/ex-cyberhacker/recent mercenary army leader, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, goes rogue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jerrine Tan
title: What Chinese Calligraphy Taught Me About Myself
description: Write your name — over and over. You’ll be surprised what you learn.
content: At the start of my first lesson in Chinese calligraphy, my teacher told me to write my name. After I scrawled it out, he said, plainly: “Now I will teach you how to write your name. And to make it beautiful.” I felt my breath catch. I was — in a word — seduced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: PGA Tour’s Pact With Saudi Wealth Fund Shows Many Details Left to Settle
description: The five-page agreement provoked a furor but included only a handful of binding provisions.
content: The PGA Tour’s tentative deal with Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund to form an alliance with the rival LIV Golf series includes only a handful of binding commitments — such as a nondisparagement agreement and a pledge to dismiss acrimonious litigation — and leaves many of the most consequential details about the future of men’s professional golf to be negotiated by the end of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Remains Found in California Wilderness Are Identified as Those of Julian Sands
description: The British actor was reported missing in January after he went hiking alone on a trail on Mount Baldy. Last weekend, after months of intense searches, hikers found human remains in the area.
content: Human remains that were found on Saturday in the Southern California wilderness have been identified as those of the British actor Julian Sands, who had been missing since January after he went hiking in the area, the authorities said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenn Pelly
title: Anohni Isn’t Afraid of the Darkness
description: Three decades into her career, the art-pop musician is still embracing new sounds, carrying stories from the past and interrogating all kinds of power.
content: Anohni requested to meet at night. Street lamps cast a soft glow onto the trees of Washington Square Park in Manhattan, and speaking for three invigorating hours on a spring Friday after dark, she illuminated histories within it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Teen Flying a Drone Discovers 2 Trapped in Car in a Flooded Sinkhole
description: The earth had swallowed the S.U.V. before the 18-year-old flew his drone near a canal. Two people were in the vehicle as the sinkhole filled with water, the authorities said, and they needed help.
content: A teenager in a rural Colorado town had sent his drone soaring in the sky to catch sweeping views of the floodwaters that were unleashed by recent downpours when he made a startling discovery on Saturday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: kinetic
description: This word has appeared in 140 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word kinetic has appeared in 135 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 20 in “A Compact Home Office With Something Extra: It’s Also a Train” by Tim McKeough:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: A Russian missile hits a crowded restaurant in Kramatorsk, killing at least 4.
description: More than 40 people were wounded in the strike, which hit a popular restaurant in Kramatorsk’s city center at dinnertime.
content: A Russian missile strike tore into a popular pizza restaurant at dinnertime in the eastern Ukrainian city of Kramatorsk on Tuesday evening, killing at least four people and injuring more than 40 others, according to Ukrainian officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: After Montana Banned TikTok, Users Sued. TikTok Is Footing Their Bill.
description: The popular video service had deflected questions about its involvement in the creators’ lawsuit for more than a month.
content: When five TikTok creators in Montana filed a lawsuit last month, saying the state’s new ban of the app violated their First Amendment rights and far outstripped the government’s legal authority, it appeared to be a grass-roots effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Couple Are Killed Just Before Celebrating 50th Wedding Anniversary
description: A suspect, Christopher Ferguson, 41, of Newton, Mass., was arrested on Monday, more than a day after the couple and a relative were found stabbed to death at their home.
content: A couple celebrating their 50th anniversary were expected at Sunday Mass to renew their vows. Their family and friends waited, but the guests of honor never arrived. Instead, they and another family member were found slain in their home that morning in the suburban city of Newton, Mass., in what the authorities described as a seemingly random attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: McCarthy Questions Strength of Trump’s Candidacy, Then Quickly Backtracks
description: The House speaker angered Donald J. Trump’s allies by saying he did not know whether the former president was the strongest candidate to beat President Biden.
content: Speaker Kevin McCarthy on Tuesday declared Donald J. Trump the “strongest political opponent” against President Biden, rushing to make clear his loyalty to the former president just hours after suggesting in a televised interview that Mr. Trump might not be the Republican presidential candidate best positioned to prevail in the 2024 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mac Schwerin
title: A.I. and TV Ads Were Made for Each Other
description: A string of uncanny videos show what generative A.I. and advertising have in common: They chew up the cultural subconscious and spit it back at us.
content: Even if I didn’t work in advertising, I would be a connoisseur of commercials. You’re probably one, too. Think of all the tropes you’ve ingested over the years — the forest-green hatchbacks conquering rugged Western landscapes, the miles of mozzarella stretched by major pizza chains. These are the images that let you know what kind of pitch you’re watching, so you won’t be confused when the brand shows up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Robin
title: Robert Black, Bass Virtuoso of the Avant-Garde, Is Dead at 67
description: As part of the influential Bang on a Can All-Stars, he helped popularize experimental music through international tours and well-regarded albums.
content: Robert Black, a virtuoso bassist who collaborated with prominent composers including Philip Glass and John Cage and was a founding member of the influential Bang on a Can All-Stars ensemble, died on Thursday at his home in Hartford, Conn. He was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed and Ivan Penn
title: A Giant Wind Farm Is Taking Root Off Massachusetts
description: The offshore energy project will have turbines taller than any building in Boston, but they will be barely visible from Martha’s Vineyard.
content: On a chilly June day, with the Massachusetts island of Martha’s Vineyard just over the distant horizon, a low-riding, green-hulled vessel finished hammering a steel column nearly 100 feet into the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Inflation Proves Persistent as It Moves Through the Eurozone Economy
description: Christine Lagarde, the president of the European Central Bank, called for “more persistent policy” to stifle price rises.
content: The nature of the inflation problem in the eurozone is changing, and interest rates will need to be higher for longer than policymakers and investors once estimated, Christine Lagarde, the president of the European Central Bank, said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salvatore Mercogliano
title: The Story of the Titan Submersible Has Not Ended
description: The loss of the Titan must lead to better safety, just as the loss of the Titanic did.
content: When Rear Adm. John Mauger, the commander of the First Coast Guard District, addressed the cameras last Thursday, four days had passed with no word on the fate of the Titan submersible or the five people it carried. After the long wait, the news that all five were presumed dead, from an instantaneous collapse of the vessel under tremendous pressure, sounded to many like an agonizing but definitive conclusion to the story. Lt. Samantha Corcoran added that there were no more scheduled briefings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: ‘Hijack,’ With Idris Elba, Is a Throwback Thriller
description: This Apple TV+ series aims to subvert expectations while delivering the reliable fun of a tense action drama. “It’s really well-done escapism,” Elba said.
content: A few years ago, the writer-producer George Kay was commuting by train from his home in London to France, where he was working on the series “Lupin.” Suddenly, as the train went through a tunnel under the English Channel, it stopped. Kay, ever the writer, put his imagination and anxiety to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sloane Crosley
title: For a Writer in Lockdown, Real Life and Fiction Are All Mixed Up
description: In Tom Rachman’s “The Imposters,” a novelist tries to write one last work, using people from her life.
content: Tom Rachman has an ear for the washed up, for balls of human desperation, for outsize prides with scratched patinas. His debut, “The Imperfectionists,” an elegy for print media, centered on the personal dramas of a newspaper staff in Rome. His subsequent novels, “The Rise and Fall of Great Powers” and “The Italian Teacher,” were equally empathetic portraits of those living in the shadows. (The English-Canadian Rachman was a foreign-news editor at The Associated Press; the journalist in him ticks on.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: For Lack of $15 and $23 Cancer Drugs, Lives Are at Risk
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, June 26, 2023.
content: “The necessity for a durable solution is growing greater by the day. Patients are left hanging.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azeen Ghorayshi
title: Landmark Study Shows Higher Suicide Risk for Transgender People
description: Using four decades of health data from Denmark, the study offers the clearest picture yet of the suicide risk among transgender people.
content: Transgender people in Denmark have a significantly higher risk of suicide than other groups, according to an exhaustive analysis of health and legal records from nearly seven million people over the last four decades. The study is the first in the world to analyze national suicide data for this group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer and Jeremy W. Peters
title: How Fox News (Yes, Fox News) Managed to Beat ‘The Tonight Show’
description: Greg Gutfeld has installed his brand of insult conservatism as the institutional voice for the next generation of Fox News viewer. And it’s catching on.
content: One evening in May, the most-watched man in late-night television these days staked out a curious if characteristic position: A 38-year-old teacher who allegedly had sex with a 16-year-old student, the host said, was the hero this nation needed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Benjamin Weiser
title: Report on Epstein’s Death Finds Errors and Mismanagement at Manhattan Jail
description: The inspector general’s report comes nearly four years after Jeffrey Epstein, 66, was found dead in his cell with a bedsheet tied around his neck.
content: Jeffrey Epstein, who was found dead in a cell with a bedsheet tied around his neck in 2019, died by suicide, not foul play — after a cascade of negligence and mismanagement at the now-shuttered federal jail in Manhattan where he was housed, according to the Justice Department’s inspector general.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrei Kolesnikov
title: Yesterday’s Putin Is Gone
description: He survived a brief revolt, but the cracks in his system are now evident.
content: MOSCOW — On the day of Yevgeny Prigozhin’s ill-fated uprising in Russia, Moscow fell silent. Traffic was sparse on Saturday, and there were few people on the streets. Events were canceled, and parks were closed as virtually everyone stayed inside, glued to the internet as Mr. Prigozhin’s private army convoy headed toward the Russian capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu, Anna Momigliano and Joe Orovic
title: Going to Europe This Summer? You’re Not Alone.
description: After three years of pandemic restrictions, travelers are flocking to Europe in record numbers, despite high airfares, limited accommodations and crowded sites. Here’s what you might encounter.
content: Between the time that Aiden Judson and his wife, Laura, picked Sicily as their honeymoon destination and their actual trip in early June, something significant happened: the second season of “The White Lotus.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Benfey
title: A Literary Take on a Notorious Crime Finds More Doubt Than Truth
description: In “A Thread of Violence,” Mark O’Connell investigates an infamous Irish murder case that eludes explanation, refusing to cohere into a single narrative.
content: In “The Silent Woman” (1994), her merciless dissection of literary biography (that genre in which “the remaining secrets of the famous dead are taken from them and dumped out in full view of the world”), Janet Malcolm identified a version of biographical narrative — the kind she herself preferred — that doesn’t mesh with readers’ expectations of authorial certainty. “What the reader has usually heard in the text,” she writes, “is the sound of doubt, the sound of a crack opening in the wall of the biographer’s self-assurance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: 115 Degrees Fahrenheit
description: Summer technically just began, and parts of the U.S. already have dangerous heat.
content: Today, New Orleans will reach 113 degrees in the heat index. Houston will reach 111. Mobile, Ala., and Jackson, Miss., will also surpass 110. And those are only a few of the places that will experience dangerous heat this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: ChatGPT Made a Guest Appearance at the Marc Jacobs Three-Minute Fashion Show
description: So much to think about, so little time.
content: When did Marc Jacobs, erstwhile downtown darling turned New York fashion éminence grise, become a philosopher of the modern condition?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Sierra Leone’s President Re-Elected, Barely Avoiding a Runoff
description: The main opposition candidate has rejected the results, and election observers have raised concerns over the lack of transparency during the vote count.
content: President Julius Maada Bio won re-election in the West African nation of Sierra Leone on Tuesday, a result rejected by his main opponent and questioned by some observers who cited a lack of transparency in the vote tallying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grayson Haver Currin
title: How Shahzad Ismaily Became Musicians’ Favorite Musician
description: Born with a rare genetic disorder, the multi-instrumentalist felt like a permanent outsider as a child. He now wields those lessons as one of music’s most coveted collaborators.
content: Shahzad Ismaily cannot regulate his body temperature. He was born without sweat glands, or at least, not very many.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Diagnosed With Tourette’s, Lewis Capaldi Takes a Break From Touring
description: After performing at Glastonbury Festival over the weekend, Capaldi, the popular Scottish singer-songwriter, said he would stop touring “for the foreseeable future.”
content: The Scottish musician Lewis Capaldi announced on Tuesday that he would take a break from touring “for the foreseeable future,” including the remainder of his current world tour, in order to adjust to life with Tourette’s syndrome, with which he was diagnosed last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Bobby Osborne, Mandolinist Who Flouted Bluegrass Convention, Dies at 91
description: The band he led with his brother broke new ground with an unusually broad repertoire, unorthodox instrumentation and untraditional vocal harmonies.
content: Bobby Osborne, the singer and mandolin player who with his younger brother, Sonny, led one of the most groundbreaking bands in the history of bluegrass, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Gallatin, Tenn., a suburb of Nashville. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: His Glory Fading, a Russian Warlord Took One Last Stab at Power
description: Whatever the Wagner uprising says about Vladimir Putin’s hold on the Kremlin, it is also the story of a mercurial mercenary leader’s growing desperation.
content: Well before Yevgeny V. Prigozhin seized a major Russian military hub and ordered an armed march on Moscow, posing a startling and dramatic threat to President Vladimir V. Putin, the caterer-turned-mercenary boss was losing his own personal war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: A New Law Aims to Stop Pregnancy Discrimination at Work
description: Here’s what the legislation entails.
content: On Tuesday, a new federal law that requires employers to provide “reasonable accommodations” for pregnant and postpartum workers went into effect, expanding protections for millions of people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: University Sues Cleaning Service After Freezer Mishap Destroys 20 Years of Research
description: Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute said that the cleaning service failed to properly train a janitor and is seeking $1 million in damages.
content: For 20 years, a Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute professor had been working on what the university described as potentially groundbreaking work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Ben Protess and William K. Rashbaum
title: Court Throws Out New York’s Civil Case Against Ivanka Trump
description: The decision could mean that claims against Donald J. Trump and his company might also be limited.
content: A New York appeals court on Tuesday dismissed the New York attorney general’s civil case against Ivanka Trump and potentially limited the case against Donald J. Trump and his business, which is set to go to trial in October.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Why Do I Wake Up Right Before My Alarm?
description: Experts have some theories.
content: Q: Sometimes I wake up a minute or two before my alarm is set to go off. Is this normal? And why does my body do this?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carla Sosenko
title: New Tours Mean No More FOMO for Plus-Size Travelers
description: Five companies dedicated to size-inclusive travel aim to bring community and reassurance to people in bigger bodies.
content: Vacation is meant to be relaxing, exhilarating and insert all the other positive adjectives you like, but it is often stressful and disappointing. Traveling while fat can be both of those things, as well as dehumanizing and FOMO-inducing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: L.S.U. Crushes Florida, 18-4, to Win Baseball National Title
description: A day after allowing the most runs in College World Series history, the Tigers found more than enough offense of their own to claim their seventh championship.
content: After Florida forced a winner-take-all Game 3 in the baseball College World Series championship series by scoring the most runs in tournament history on Sunday, the Gators took a 2-0 lead over Louisiana State in the first inning on Monday and seemed poised to capture the title.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Wagner Chief in Exile
description: Also, American views on China continue to sour.
content: Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of the Wagner mercenary group, arrived in Belarus yesterday, state media reported. The Russian authorities dropped criminal charges against him and his fighters after he called off an uprising over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Facing Bankruptcy After a $700 Million Bailout
description: Three years after receiving a pandemic relief loan, the trucking company Yellow has repaid little of the money and is warning that it could soon run out of cash.
content: A beleaguered trucking business that received a $700 million pandemic-era loan from the federal government may be forced to file for bankruptcy protection this summer amid a dispute with its union, a development that could leave American taxpayers stuck with a failed company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Anthony Fauci Will Join Faculty at Georgetown University
description: Dr. Fauci was the federal government’s top infectious disease expert for decades, and helped steer the U.S. response to Covid-19.
content: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, who served as the federal government’s top infectious disease specialist for nearly 40 years and played a key role in steering the United States through the coronavirus pandemic, will join the faculty of Georgetown University in Washington next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Nasrin’s Kitchen Offers Persian Cuisine Just Steps From Bergdorf Goodman and Tiffany & Co.
description: Michael Cecchi-Azzolina opens his own place in the West Village, the 11 Howard Hotel adds La Rubia and more restaurant news.
content: Nasrin Rejali, who arrived from Iran by way of Istanbul in 2016, cooked for Eat Offbeat, a catering company that employs refugees. In 2020 she started Nasrin’s Kitchen, a catering company in Queens, and is now opening a restaurant to showcase her Persian cooking just steps from Bergdorf Goodman and Tiffany & Co. On the second floor of the space that housed Betony, and a couple of Russian restaurants before that, the dining room decorated with traditional Persian touches has about 60 seats. It’s the setting for dishes like kashk badmejon, sautéed eggplant; ash reshteh, a Persian noodle soup with vegetables; basmati rice dishes (chelo) with beef stew, chicken or ground meat; and assorted kebabs often fragrant with saffron and other seasonings. Ms. Rejali said she plans to do the cooking. Her son Arta Kasra will handle the management side of the business. The restaurant has a bar and will serve mostly beer and wine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Melanie Challenger
description: The June 27, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Melanie Challenger. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: What It Is Like to Teach in the Cross Hairs of Ron DeSantis
description: Florida is ground zero of what feels like a culture of repression from the McCarthy era.
content: Becoming a professor has never been a path to riches. But it once promised a path to professional stability, mostly for white men. As the professoriate has become more female since the 1990s and marginally more nonwhite, politicians and culture warmongers have dusted off their depictions of us as out-of-touch commies. You can convince a loud minority of the American population that college professors are indoctrinating young adults with Marxist theory porn when, in reality, most of us would be happy to persuade students to read the syllabus. Who people imagine is teaching makes it easier for them to imagine an enemy. That is a big reason the professional post-Ph.D. path has been crumbling — more steadily for some parts of the professoriate than for others, but it has not been a yellow brick road for most of us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: At the Top of Their Renovation Wish List: A Fire Pole
description: The oceanfront home had spectacular views, but the interiors were too conservative for the couple who bought it. Not anymore.
content: David and Davin Wedel were living in a Boston condominium in 2016, awaiting the birth of their twin daughters, when it occurred to them that they might need more space for their family. So they began casually looking at houses outside the city, just to get a feel for the market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Man Is Sentenced in $9 Million Cow Manure Ponzi Scheme
description: Raymond Brewer defrauded investors by falsely telling them he was building machines that could convert cow manure into biogas, federal prosecutors said.
content: A California man was sentenced on Monday to more than six years in prison for running an $8.75 million Ponzi scheme that hinged on a nonexistent factory that was supposed to create green energy out of cow manure, federal prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Competing Accounts of Justice Dept.’s Handling of Hunter Biden Case
description: An I.R.S. investigator’s testimony describing strains over the inquiry into President Biden’s son is at odds with the version laid out by Attorney General Merrick Garland.
content: At a Senate hearing in March, Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, spent seven minutes grilling Attorney General Merrick B. Garland about the Hunter Biden investigation, reading a series of unusually specific queries from a paper in his hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rochelle P. Walensky
title: What I Need to Tell America Before I Leave the C.D.C.
description: The departing C.D.C. director shares a message for Americans.
content: ‌Exactly one year after the first laboratory-confirmed case of Covid-19 was identified in the United States, I began my tenure as the 19th director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. At the time, vaccines were available, but new variants continued to emerge. I viewed my primary charge as bringing this country from the dark and tragic pandemic days into a more restored place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: It’s Primary Day in New York City
description: Two district attorney races and a number of City Council seats will be on the ballot today, with some races featuring ranked-choice voting.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday — Primary Day in New York City. We’ll get an overview of what to expect if you’re voting. And the longtime Times reporter Sam Roberts will reminisce about Richard Ravitch, who helped the city navigate crises in the 1970s and 1980s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: Klimt’s ‘Lady With a Fan’ Brings $108.4 Million, Auction Record for the Artist
description: The price was the highest for a public sale in Europe, beating the $104.3 million that a Giacometti sculpture brought in 2010.
content: Post-Brexit London regained some credibility as the capital of Europe’s high-value art market on Tuesday when a radiant portrait by Gustav Klimt, “Lady With a Fan,” sold at Sotheby’s for 85.3 million pounds with fees, or about $108.4 million. The price was an auction high for the renowned Austrian artist and was the highest for a public sale in Europe, beating Alberto Giacometti’s “Walking Man I,” which sold for $104.3 million in 2010, also at Sotheby’s in London.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anya Yurchyshyn
title: When Going Home Becomes a Fact-Finding Mission
description: In her new memoir, the Ukrainian-born journalist Victoria Belim returns to her homeland to find the missing pieces in the puzzle of her family’s history.
content: “When something of ours, something we took for granted as being ours, is destroyed before our eyes,” writes the Ukrainian-born journalist Victoria Belim, early in her absorbing memoir, “we are destroyed along with it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell, Jonathan Swan and Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis’s Pitch to New Hampshire Is All About a State 1,000 Miles South
description: Focusing heavily on Florida at his first town-hall event in the Granite State, Ron DeSantis drew a reception that was sometimes warm, sometimes more skeptical — especially on the issue of abortion.
content: At his first town-hall event in New Hampshire, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida talked on Tuesday about illegal immigration in Texas, crime in Chicago, disorder on the streets of San Francisco and the wonders of nearly every aspect of Florida — a state he mentioned about 80 times.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A.I. Outshines in Health Care. At Paperwork.
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 27, 2023.
content: “In medicine, we can’t tolerate hallucinations.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Left Any Room She Entered’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: You were a businessman seated next to me on a flight. I was a 19-year-old who had gotten an abortion three days before. I asked a flight attendant for a blanket but she said they didn’t have any. As my lip trembled from the news, you took off your suit jacket and draped it over my shoulders. I wept into the sleeves, finding strange comfort in the mature smell of your cologne. We didn’t speak for the duration of the short flight, but for those 60 minutes, I felt held. — Rachel Young
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Embracing Beige Flags: The Week 1 Winner of Our Summer Reading Contest
description: Katie Chung, 17, chose an article from the Style section about a TikTok trend that she thinks has broader implications.
content: Our annual Summer Reading Contest invites teenagers around the world to tell us what New York Times pieces get their attention and why. This week, the first of 10, we received 725 entries. Thank you to everyone who participated, and congratulations to our winner, Katie Chung, as well as to the runners-up and honorable mentions we honor below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: ‘Mindful Breathing’ Will Now Be Required in New York City Schools
description: “There’s a science to breathing,” Mayor Eric Adams said when announcing the initiative, which will begin next year as a way to improve student well-being.
content: Take a deep breath. Relax your body. And slowly exhale through your mouth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder, Lauren Hirsch and Kevin Draper
title: How the PGA Tour’s Deal With Saudi Arabia’s Wealth Fund Could Collapse
description: The tentative agreement has been the talk of golf, but there is no guarantee the pact that aims to bring the tour and LIV Golf under one umbrella will overcome every threat.
content: Golf’s big deal — a planned partnership between the PGA Tour and Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund — is not how big deals are ordinarily done.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Restaurant Review: Superiority Burger Has the Courage of Its Quirks
description: Brooks Headley could have cloned his wildly popular vegetarian spot. Instead, its new space doubles down on idiosyncrasy.
content: The new Superiority Burger on Avenue A is about 10 times larger than the original, a 240-square-foot below-grade box on East Ninth Street that was outgrown “on the first day,” according to Brooks Headley, the chef and an owner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: Korean Corn Dogs and Uyghur Noodles Near Forest Hills Stadium
description: If you’re headed to a concert at this former tennis complex, here are a few options for food.
content: There are a few summer inevitabilities: A heat wave that will test the limits of your window air-conditioner. Sweating on a subway platform. One of your favorite bands or musicians playing a show at Forest Hills Stadium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Salaam, of Central Park 5, Holds Large Lead in Harlem Council Primary
description: Primaries were contested Tuesday for a range of New York City Council seats, district attorneys in the Bronx and Queens, and offices throughout New York State.
content: Yusef Salaam, one of the so-called Central Park 5, wrongfully convicted of the rape and assault of a female jogger, held a commanding lead over two Assembly members in what would be a major upset in the Democratic primary for a Harlem City Council seat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: To Let Your Mind Roam, Travel on Foot
description: For a new Travel package, 13 writers took scenic, personal, inventive and multicultural strolls, often getting advice from locals along the way.
content: Not every walk is a walk in the park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Lordstown Motors, an Electric Truck Maker, Files for Bankruptcy
description: The company bought a shuttered General Motors plant in Ohio but struggled to produce its pickup truck.
content: Lordstown Motors, the troubled electric vehicle company that bought a shuttered General Motors factory in Ohio with grand plans to create the Tesla of pickup trucks, filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas
title: In Kremlin Stagecraft, Putin Tries to Rewrite the Mutiny in Russia
description: President Vladimir V. Putin appeared only once during a mercenary’s daylong mutiny against the military. He was all over Russian TV on Tuesday, seeking to project an image of control.
content: During a mercenary’s daylong mutiny against Russia’s military, President Vladimir V. Putin appeared just once, vowing “decisive actions” to take on “a betrayal of our people.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
title: Audio Undercuts Trump’s Assertion He Did Not Have Classified Document
description: A recording of a meeting in 2021 in which the former president described a sensitive document in front of him appears to contradict his recent assertion that the material was just news clippings.
content: An audio recording of former President Donald J. Trump in 2021 discussing what he called a “highly confidential” document about Iran that he acknowledged he could not declassify because he was out of office appears to contradict his recent assertion that the material he was referring to was simply news clippings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marco Roth
title: Called the French ‘Huck Finn,’ This Book Has Pleasures All Its Own
description: Henri Bosco’s lyrical 1945 novella, “The Child and the River,” tells the story of two boys and a boat.
content: The life and literary career of Henri Bosco spanned two centuries, two world wars, two continents, an empire and its aftermath. Born in 1888 in Avignon, he trained as a composer, spent World War I on the Balkan front, then became a teacher in France’s “overseas departments” — notably in Rabat — until Moroccan independence in 1955.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: U.S. Sees First Cases of Local Malaria Transmission in Two Decades
description: Five people, four in Florida and one in Texas, have acquired malaria in the United States in recent months.
content: In the last two months, at least five people, four in Florida and one in Texas, have been infected with malaria in the United States, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said in a health advisory on Monday. These are the first known cases of locally acquired malaria in the country since 2003.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: ‘Taylor Mac’s 24-Decade History of Popular Music’ Review: Wish You Were There
description: Only 650 people got to experience one of the 21st century’s artistic feats, until this documentary. Unfortunately, it misses some of the performance’s key aspects.
content: The writer and performer Taylor Mac spent the first half of the 2010s developing an epic project, “A 24-Decade History of Popular Music,” that covered 240 years’ worth of American history. Mac would perform large excerpts at concerts, then on Oct. 8-9, 2016, did the whole caboodle as an ultramarathon of 246 songs. The show took over St. Ann’s Warehouse, in Brooklyn, in a 24-hour-long “radical faerie realness ritual sacrifice” that amounted to a transcendent artistic and political gesture. (Full disclosure: I was there.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: If Biden Wanted to Ease U.S.-China Tensions, Would Americans Let Him?
description: In polls, Americans’ views of China are starting to resemble their views of the Soviet Union decades ago. That could make it harder to mend ties.
content: As tensions between their countries mount, President Biden and Xi Jinping, China’s leader, have repeatedly pushed back on comparisons to the Cold War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: States Passed a Record Number of Transgender Laws. Here’s What They Say.
description: Many of the bills denied certain medical care to transgender people, while others targeted bathroom use and preferred personal pronouns.
content: Statehouses around the country this year have been consumed by fights over laws governing transgender people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miranda S. Spivack
title: More Data in the Cloud Means More Centers on the Ground to Move It
description: The need for data centers has soared, fueled by remote work and the growth of high-speed streaming. But finding the necessary land and energy can be a challenge.
content: Past the dense western suburbs of Washington, the vistas widen into open stretches of fields and farmland — a panorama frequently interrupted by massive, windowless buildings housing the high-speed computers that make technologies like 5G and artificial intelligence possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Prigozhin’s Mutiny Against Putin’s Reign of Lies
description: But do ordinary Russians want to know the truth?
content: For a good understanding of the psychology of modern Russia, it helps to read Peter Pomerantsev’s “Nothing Is True and Everything Is Possible,” published in 2014, the year Vladimir Putin seized Crimea using “little green men” who either were or were not Russian soldiers. The book captures the qualities of cultivated unreality and sinister surrealism that, for a day last week, were punctured by Yevgeny Prigozhin’s aborted mutiny.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas E. Ricks
title: Reading the Tea Leaves on the End of the War in Ukraine
description: In several recent books, experts on Russia and Ukraine weigh the importance of the Wagner Group and try to predict how Putin’s invasion will play out.
content: The Russian invasion of Ukraine that began in February last year has led to the biggest war in Europe in many generations. Even before the Wagner Group — the 50,000-strong paramilitary force that had been fighting alongside Russian soldiers — seized control of military sites in the southwestern Russian city of Rostov-on-Don last week, with the apparent aim of toppling Moscow’s military command, the incursion into Ukraine looked like a major failure for its instigator, President Vladimir Putin. Within a month of the war’s onset, it had already become “a [foul]-up of historic proportions,” as one veteran Ukraine correspondent recently put it. So it is no wonder that this year brings several new books aiming to summarize the conflict and to mull how it might end.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 6 Odes to Ohio
description: The state has inspired memorable songs by Randy Newman, R.E.M., King Princess and more.
content: For six of the past seven summers, I’ve spent a long weekend visiting college friends in northern Ohio — a part of the country with which I was previously unfamiliar but has now come to feel like a home away from home. A highlight of these trips is always, weather permitting, when we get to tube lazily down the Cuyahoga River. We tend to start the drive with this excursion’s unofficial theme song: “Burn On,” Randy Newman’s wry but warmly sung ode to that time in 1969 that the infamously polluted Cuyahoga caught fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Ryan Seacrest Named New ‘Wheel of Fortune’ Host
description: The game show has demonstrated remarkable durability even as traditional television has declined in the wake of streaming entertainment.
content: Ryan Seacrest, the dexterous Hollywood master of ceremonies, was named the next host of “Wheel of Fortune” on Tuesday, succeeding the longtime host Pat Sajak in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: A Mother Had Three Minutes to Address Her Son’s Killer
description: Adriana Vance lost her son Raymond in a mass shooting seven months ago. The night before she would face the shooter in court, she still wasn’t sure what she would say.
content: The night before Adriana Vance addressed her son’s killer in a Colorado courtroom, she was still searching for the right words.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Luis Arraez Is Chasing One of Baseball’s Sacred Feats and Sports Divinity
description: Ted Williams, LeBron James and other venerated athletes have set some of sports’ untouchable records. The chance to challenge their marks is what keeps us watching.
content: All season, Luis Arraez had been in hot pursuit of baseball immortals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: An angry speech by Vladimir Putin.
content: Speaking publicly for the first time in two days, a visibly angry Vladimir Putin, Russia’s president, denounced as “blackmail” a weekend rebellion by the Wagner mercenary group even as he defended his response and hinted at leniency for those who took part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: How Do I Love Thee? Let Me Etch It Into the Colosseum.
description: A man decided to immortalize his visit to a Roman landmark by scratching “Ivan + Hayley 23/6/23” into the brick, using his keys.
content: A tourist decided to immortalize a visit to the Colosseum in Rome with his girlfriend recently by scratching their names into one of the walls of the nearly 2,000-year-old monument.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Shaffer
title: ‘Sin La Habana’ Review: A Long Way From Home
description: In Kaveh Nabatian’s new drama, an Afro-Cuban dancer tries to bring his girlfriend to Canada through a sham marriage.
content: Kaveh Nabatian’s “Sin La Habana” is a study in contrasts: the sticky, vibrant heat of Cuba’s capital versus the pulverizing winter of Montreal; a spontaneous street performance versus the rigid formality of a ballet studio audition; a planned marriage versus an impulsive romance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: The Implications of the Failed Wagner Rebellion, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Frederic Forrest, 86, Dies; Actor Known for ‘Apocalypse Now’ and ‘The Rose’
description: He appeared in a string of films directed by Francis Ford Coppola, and his performance as Bette Midler’s love interest earned him an Oscar nomination.
content: Frederic Forrest, who appeared in more than 80 movies and television shows in a career that began in the 1960s, and who turned in perhaps his two most memorable performances in the same year, 1979, in two very different films — the romantic drama “The Rose” and the Vietnam War odyssey “Apocalypse Now” — died on Friday at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Ex-Police Chief in Maryland Gets Multiple Life Terms in Series of Arsons
description: David M. Crawford, who resigned as police chief of Laurel, Md., in 2010, targeted people he thought had slighted him, prosecutors said.
content: A former police chief in Maryland was sentenced on Tuesday to multiple life sentences for setting fires to the houses, garages and cars of people who prosecutors said he felt had slighted him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Firestone
title: A Handy Guide to the Republican Definition of a Crime
description: The party of law and order has given new meaning to “law and order.” Here’s what it considers crimeworthy.
content: If you think Republicans are still members of the law-and-order party, you haven’t been paying close attention lately. Since the rise of Donald Trump, the Republican definition of a crime has veered sharply from the law books and become extremely selective. For readers confused about the party’s new positions on law and order, here’s a guide to what today’s Republicans consider a crime, and what they do not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: A Proto-Pizza Emerges from a Fresco on a Pompeii Wall
description: That doughy disc with delectable toppings seen in a 2,000-year-old painting is not a pizza, experts insist. But can we get one delivered anyway?
content: It may have been no pepperoni with extra cheese, but it still caught the eye of archaeologists working on the ruins of Pompeii, and not because they were hungry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: Revisiting a Midcentury Haven for Cross-Dressing Men
description: The documentary “Casa Susanna” explores the Catskills boardinghouse community that allowed denizens to express their identity when that was taboo.
content: Sébastien Lifshitz’s documentary “Casa Susanna” remembers a community of cross-dressing men and transgender women who found refuge in the Catskills in the 1950s and ’60s. Their gathering place, a Victorian boardinghouse, was christened Casa Susanna after one of its founders, Susanna Valenti, a translator and broadcaster, who was married to Marie Tonell, a New York wig maker. The couple ran Casa Susanna until the late 1960s, but its existence came to broader awareness with the 2005 publication of a book collecting Casa Susanna snapshots that had been found in a New York flea market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: At Least Three Die in Egyptian Building Collapse
description: The authorities in Alexandria said three bodies had been pulled from the rubble of the building that collapsed in the city on Monday.
content: CAIRO — At least three people were killed when a 14-story apartment building collapsed in the coastal city of Alexandria in northern Egypt, authorities said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Hunter Biden Isn’t Hiding. Even Some Democrats Are Uncomfortable.
description: Hunter Biden’s public appearances came across as a message of defiance by the president, who is determined to show that he stands by his son.
content: During last week’s state dinner at the White House, Hunter Biden seemed to be everywhere. Upbeat and gregarious, he worked the pavilion with grins and gusto, shaking hands and hugging other guests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: How ‘Swagger’ Raised Its Game
description: The cast and crew of the kinetic basketball drama explain how they built on a solid foundation to make a more ambitious second season.
content: The first season of “Swagger,” a sports drama set in the high-stakes world of high school basketball in the Washington, D.C., suburb of Seat Pleasant, Md., was released in fall 2021 to moderate critical acclaim. The creator, Reggie Rock Bythewood, and his cast and crew were proud of what they had accomplished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: How ‘Being Animal’ Could Help Us Be Better Humans
description: The environmental philosopher Melanie Challenger blurs the line long drawn between humans and animals.
content: One of the oldest human ideas is that we are somehow different from animals, somehow superior to them. That’s a mistake, argues the environmental philosopher Melanie Challenger. “Many of the things we most value — our relationships, the romantic sensations of attraction and love, pregnancy and childbirth, the pleasures of springtime, of eating a meal — are physical, largely unconscious and demonstrably animal,” she writes in her book “How to Be Animal: A New History of What It Means to Be Human.” The consequences of resisting our fellowship with other species, she argues, have been devastating to them and to the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: E.U. Border Agency Considers Pulling Out of Greece Over Migrant Abuses
description: Days after the deadliest shipwreck in the Mediterranean in years, an E.U. official said that Greek authorities continue violating the rights of migrants.
content: The human rights chief at the European Union’s border agency said last week that it could suspend operations in Greece over chronic rights abuses against migrants, potentially pulling out dozens of border guards, vessels and aircraft from a key gateway into Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamilton Cain
title: Looking Back on a Formative Friendship With Compassion
description: In her new novel, “The Rachel Incident,” Caroline O’Donoghue examines the bond between two young booksellers in Ireland.
content: The turn of the century saw L.G.B.T.Q. characters stride boldly into popular culture, shedding caricatures and claiming spaces long denied them. No television series embodied that shift more than “Will & Grace,” NBC’s ratings juggernaut that chronicled the complex friendship of Will Truman, a gay lawyer, and Grace Adler, a straight interior decorator.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia DePillis and Manuela Andreoni
title: How Countries Can Get Richer Without Wrecking the Planet
description: Economic growth is often seen as incompatible with conservation. It doesn’t have to be that way, economists say.
content: Preserve nature, or accelerate economic growth? It’s long seemed as if nations had to choose between the two. And we all know how that choice usually plays out: Our desire to accumulate wealth and our need to lift people out of poverty have pushed Earth to the brink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Starbucks to Offer ‘Clearer’ Store Décor Guidelines After Pride Clash
description: The company said it would be more specific in its policies on store decorations and reiterated its support of the L.G.B.T.Q. community.
content: Starbucks said on Monday that it would issue “clearer” guidelines on permissible store decorations after the union that represents thousands of its workers said management had prohibited some employees from putting up decorations for Pride Month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Samuel Alito Joins the Supreme Court’s Billionaires’ Club
description: The ethics crisis continues.
content: The Supreme Court ethics crisis continues, not with Clarence Thomas but with his right-wing comrade, Justice Samuel Alito.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: After Mutiny Against Putin, Russia’s Friends Have Reason to Hedge Bets
description: Leaders from Iran, Qatar and Saudi Arabia, among others, expressed support for Vladimir Putin in the face of the Wagner uprising. But concerns may linger, analysts say.
content: Even before President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia broke his public silence on Monday about the aborted mutiny that brought rogue troops to within 125 miles of Moscow, he was on the phone to the leaders of Iran, Qatar and other friendly countries, soaking up their expressions of support while presumably promising a return to stability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky and Julie Turkewitz
title: The Unexpected Rescuers Who Found Colombia’s Missing Children
description: Colombia’s Indigenous Guard has long had to fight for a space in the national narrative. Today, it is at the center of the country’s biggest story.
content: At first, he heard a soft cry. Then, just beyond the broad leaves of the jungle, Nicolás Ordóñez could make out the form of a small girl, a baby in her arms.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Kylie Minogue’s ‘Padam Padam’ and the Queer Club-Pop Canon
description: The global star’s single has become the soundtrack of Pride this year, opening fresh conversations about pop divas and their gay fans.
content: The song defining Pride month this year is Kylie Minogue’s “Padam Padam,” a thumping tease that’s lightly campy and has taken on outsize importance as a gay nightlife anthem and meme-culture staple.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Senate Report Details Jan. 6 Intelligence and Law Enforcement Failures
description: The report by Democrats provided the most comprehensive picture to date of how federal officials missed, downplayed or failed to act on multiple threats of and plans for violence.
content: Democrats on the Senate Homeland Security Committee on Tuesday released a scathing report that detailed how the F.B.I., the Department of Homeland Security and other federal agencies repeatedly ignored, downplayed or failed to share warnings of violence before the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman, Rebecca Robbins and Maureen Farrell
title: How Vivek Ramaswamy Made the Fortune Fueling His Presidential Run
description: Mr. Ramaswamy calls himself a scientist from the biotech industry, but his vast fortune stems from two huge paydays that speak to hope and hype in the world of finance.
content: On the campaign trail, as he lays out why he is a different kind of presidential candidate, Vivek Ramaswamy calls himself a Harvard-trained “scientist” from the lifesaving world of biotechnology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman, Trip Gabriel and Shane Goldmacher
title: Can DeSantis Break Trump’s Hold on New Hampshire?
description: On a campaign stop in the state, Donald Trump mused that he might move on to attacking a different rival if the Florida governor slips past second place in polls.
content: Campaigning on Tuesday in New Hampshire, Donald J. Trump expressed such confidence in his consolidation of Republican voters that he said he might soon have to find another rival to attack besides Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Julian Sands Dies at 65; Actor Played Shelley, a Warlock and a King
description: Over a 40-year screen career, the instantly recognizable Mr. Sands displayed great versatility onscreen. He died while hiking in the San Gabriel Mountains.
content: Julian Sands, a versatile British actor whose film roles included the poet Percy Bysshe Shelley, Louis XIV, a warlock, Superman’s father and a Latvian pimp, was pronounced dead on Tuesday, more than five months after disappearing while hiking alone on a trail on Mount Baldy in the San Gabriel Mountains in Southern California. He was 65.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: James Crown, Chicago Businessman and Avid Philanthropist, Dies at 70
description: He was a director of General Dynamics and served on the board of JPMorgan Chase. He was also a crucial early supporter of Barack Obama.
content: James Crown, a scion of a wealthy Chicago family who held important positions in businesses as diverse as General Dynamics, Sara Lee and JPMorgan Chase, and who became a crucial early supporter of an up-and-coming politician named Barack Obama, died in Woody Creek, Colo., on Sunday, his 70th birthday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Florida Woman Charged With Manslaughter, Not Murder, in Fatal Shooting
description: Susan Louise Lorincz was accused of killing Ajike Owens, a neighbor, after a dispute with her children in a case that spurred outrage in Florida and across the country.
content: A Florida woman accused of fatally shooting a neighbor after a dispute with her children this month will not face murder charges, a prosecutor said Monday in a carefully worded statement explaining his reasoning in the divisive case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: U.S. Pedestrian Deaths Are at Highest Level in 41 Years, Report Says
description: More than 7,500 people were struck and killed by vehicles in 2022, according to state data. Safety can be improved through infrastructure changes and traffic enforcement, the analysis said.
content: The number of pedestrians who were struck and killed by vehicles in 2022 was the highest it’s been since 1981, according to a report based on state government data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Knoxville Bishop Resigns Amid Turmoil
description: The Vatican accepted the resignation of Bishop Richard Stika, after complaints about his leadership and lawsuits over his handling of sexual abuse claims.
content: Pope Francis has accepted the resignation of the bishop of Knoxville, Tenn., the Vatican announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rejects Theory That Would Have Transformed American Elections
description: The 6-to-3 majority dismissed the “independent state legislature” theory, which would have given state lawmakers nearly unchecked power over federal elections.
content: The Supreme Court on Tuesday rejected a legal theory that would have radically reshaped how federal elections are conducted by giving state legislatures largely unchecked power to set rules for federal elections and to draw congressional maps warped by partisan gerrymandering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: Schools Bring Police Back to Campuses, Reversing Racial Justice Decisions
description: Denver’s school system is the latest to reinstate officers, responding to parental concerns over campus violence. Critics say the move will disproportionately hurt students of color.
content: In the summer of 2020, Denver school leaders quickly banished police officers from campuses and directed the funds toward social workers and psychologists. The city, like many across the nation, was roiled by protests against law enforcement after the murder of George Floyd by a Minneapolis police officer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Tesla May Have Already Won the Charging Wars
description: Deals with Ford and G.M. will make it easier to find a charger but could give Elon Musk control of critical infrastructure.
content: Mary Barra and Elon Musk may be intense business rivals, but they sounded like old pals as they chatted on Twitter this month about a deal that could help remove one of the biggest barriers to electric vehicle ownership: not enough chargers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: California Jury Pay Could Soon Increase to $100 a Day
description: A new bill would offer higher stipends to low-income jurors in Los Angeles, Alameda, Kern and other counties.
content: Californians could soon be paid far more for jury duty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: F.D.A. Wants to Regulate Prenatal Tests That Have Misled Parents
description: A booming industry has recently come under scrutiny for some of its testing, including a high rate of false positive results.
content: The U.S. government plans to regulate a booming prenatal testing market that has recently come under scrutiny for a high share of false positive results for some rare conditions and marketing that could mislead parents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: An All-Star Game Without Any Yankees? It Wouldn’t Be the First.
description: With Aaron Judge injured and Gerrit Cole not guaranteed to pitch, the Yankees could be shut out of the All-Star Game box score for only the third time in the event’s history.
content: Despite a rough stretch in which some fans have questioned the team’s relative lack of transactions in the off-season, the Yankees have had a fairly good year. They are eight games above .500; through Monday, they were in line for a wild-card spot in the postseason. If a few injured players come back strong, the Yankees will be considered a serious playoff contender.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Mary Wilson, Will Reid, Carlos Prieto, Shannon Lin, Patricia Willens, Devon Taylor, Elisheba Ittoop, Diane Wong, Rowan Niemisto, Brad Fisher and Chris Wood
title: Speaker McCarthy Has Lost Control of His House
description: Right-wing anger over the speaker’s debt deal with President Biden has brought the House to a grinding halt.
content: Earlier this month, a group of hard-right Republicans hijacked the floor of the House of Representatives in protest against Speaker Kevin McCarthy. The mutiny, staged by nearly a dozen members of the ultraconservative House Freedom Caucus, raised questions about whether the speaker could continue to govern his slim and fractious majority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Trump Criminal Case Likely to Remain in N.Y. State Court, Judge Says
description: The judge, Alvin K. Hellerstein, said he was not inclined to move the Manhattan district attorney’s case against the former president to federal court.
content: A judge on Tuesday indicated that he was likely to deny a request from lawyers for Donald J. Trump to move a New York State criminal case against the former president to federal court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Betray a Secret

author: By Stefanos Chen and Ana Ley
title: Migrant Women Find Work Building New York, Their Adopted City
description: Women who have come to New York City seeking asylum are entering the male-dominated construction industry, despite dangerous conditions, exploitation and sexism on the job.
content: Roxana García sat in a packed classroom on a recent night in Jackson Heights, Queens, with 38 strangers — a chef, an I.T. technician, and a business manager among them — all with a single goal: To get a job in construction, one of the few industries open to New York’s surging migrant population.

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: A Jew and 16 ‘Nerf Nazis’ Meet Cute in ‘Just for Us’
description: Is it a stand-up act or a morality play? Either way, Alex Edelman’s look at race, religion and the limits of empathy is at home on Broadway.
content: It may be too much to ask a human hummingbird like Alex Edelman to try to stick to the subject. In “Just for Us,” his three-jokes-per-minute one-man show, he zooms from punchline to punchline almost as fast as he caroms around the stage of the Hudson Theater. (At 34, he’s part of what he calls the overmedicated ADHD generation.) If you haven’t read about his act coming to Broadway, you might assume from his introduction — in which he describes his usual style as “benign silliness” and says this “isn’t Ibsen” — that you are in for a cheerful evening of laughs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: At Larry Kramer’s Memorial, a Gathering of Friends and Enemies
description: Tony Kushner and Anthony Fauci were among the speakers who fondly described difficult moments with the irascible writer and activist.
content: Decades before Dr. Anthony S. Fauci became a household name during the coronavirus pandemic, one of his detractors wrote that he was “a murderer” and “a liar” who “should be put before a firing squad.”

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Smoky Air From Canadian Wildfires Blankets Midwestern Skies
description: Chicago residents were warned to stay indoors or wear masks, and the popular paths along Lake Michigan were quiet.
content: Chicago and much of the Upper Midwest were blanketed with a smoky haze from Canadian wildfires on Tuesday, leaving many residents of the nation’s third-largest city startled by the sudden decline in air quality and donning masks when they ventured outside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The Supreme Court Rejects a Once-Fringe Elections Theory
description: Also, the Wagner chief begins exile in Belarus. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: Justices on the country’s highest court rejected a legal theory that would have radically reshaped how elections are conducted by giving state legislatures largely unchecked power to set rules for federal elections and to draw congressional maps warped by partisan gerrymandering. The 6-to-3 decision was cheered by voting rights advocates who feared an undemocratic fallout if the Supreme Court had ruled the other way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: The Supreme Court Just Helped Save American Democracy From Trumpism
description: The end of the “independent state legislature” doctrine.
content: To understand both the Trump-led Republican effort to overturn the 2020 election and the lingering Republican bitterness surrounding that contest, it’s important to remember that the G.O.P.’s attack on American democracy had two aspects: a conspiracy theory and a coup theory. On Tuesday, the Supreme Court dealt a blow to both. In a case called Moore v. Harper, the court rejected the “independent state legislature” doctrine, reaffirmed the soundness of the 2020 election and secured the integrity of elections to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Angela Bassett and Mel Brooks Are Among Those to Receive Honorary Oscars
description: The Sundance Institute executive Michelle Satter and the film editor Carol Littleton will also get prizes at the Governors Awards ceremony in November.
content: Just a few months after Angela Bassett came close to clinching a supporting-actress Oscar for “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever,” she’ll become one of four Hollywood figures to receive an honorary Oscar at this year’s Governors Awards, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has announced. Also getting honorary Oscars will be the director Mel Brooks and the editor Carol Littleton, while the Sundance Institute’s Michelle Satter will be presented with the Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award.
source.name: The New York Times
